fr:title.text: Formal method to calculate the harmonic conjugate

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Formal method to calculate the harmonic conjugate

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose u is the real part of some holomorphic function f. Then we have 2 u(x, y) = f(z) + \overline {f(z)}. If we could extend the coordinates x and y to complex numbers, then similar to what happens in the tangent space, we have a (z, \bar {z}) coordinate system with z = x + i y and \bar {z} = x - i y acting as independent variables in \mathbb {C}^2.

f(z) should only depend on z and \overline {f(z)} should only depend on \bar {z}. So we can write the latter as another function g(\bar {z}). Since 2 u = f(z) + g(\bar {z}), we can look at the value at the point (z, \bar {z}) = (\alpha , 0) where \alpha \in \mathbb {C}, which corresponds to x = \alpha / 2 and y = - i \alpha / 2. Hence 2 u(\alpha / 2, - i \alpha / 2) = f(\alpha ) + g(0), which determines f up to some constant. This method requires an analytic expression of u(x, y), so it makes sense to plug in complex numbers into x and y.

Considering \mathbb {C} as a two dimensional real space, the tangent space at a point (take zero as an example) is \mathbb {R}^2. It comes equipped with a complex structure J sending \partial _x \mapsto \partial _y and \partial _y \mapsto -\partial _x, acting as multiplication by i. A (real) smooth function \mathbb {C} \to \mathbb {C} then has a Jacobian at each point, which is a 2 \times 2 matrix M. The Cauchy–Riemann equations then imposes a condition on this matrix, which can be written as J M = M J.

It is sometimes convenient to complexify this vector space \mathbb {R}^2 \otimes \mathbb {C} = \mathbb {C}^2. This corresponds to formally allowing the x and y components to be complex-valued. Of course this only happens in the tangent space, and the coordinate functions cannot be extended to complex domains. The Jacobian then extends to the complexified tangent space. This space has an alternative basis \partial _z = \frac {1}{2}(\partial _x - i \partial _y) \quad \text {and}\quad \partial _{\bar {z}} = \frac {1}{2}(\partial _x + i \partial _y). In this basis, the Cauchy–Riemann equation can be written as \partial _{\bar {z}} f = 0.
This gives a heuristic procedure for finding the harmonic conjugate of a function.
